questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is a pigment-producing species of mycobacteria?
questions.explanation:
182 
Sold by @itachibot Mycobacterium scrofulaceum is a pigment-producing species of mycobacteria. M. scrofulaceum is a scotochromogen which produces yellow or orange colored pigments, even in 
the dark. It belongs to group II of Runyon's classification. It can cause scrofula or cervical adenitis 
in children. M.ulcerans, M.avium intracellulare complex (MAC), and M. xenopi belong to group III-non 
photochromogens as they do not form pigment even on exposure to light.

questions.question:
Question 2: A microbiologist working with mycobacteria notes moist, smooth, flat, white colonies growing 
on Lowenstein-Jensen media. Which species of mycobacteria is she likely studying?
questions.explanation:
The species of mycobacteria being studied here is Mycobacterium bovis. It forms moist, smooth, 
flat, white colonies on Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) media that break-up easily when touched. Mycobacterium bovis belongs to the Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex. It causes 
tuberculosis-like disease in humans. Lowenstein–Jensen medium is a commonly used, egg-based, selective media for mycobacteria. It 
contains: • Egg- Provides fatty acids and protein required for metabolism • Malachite green- Prevents the growth of contaminants. Makes it a selective medium. • Mineral salt solution- Buffer • Glycerol- Source of carbon, favors growth of M. tuberculosis, but not M. bovis. LJ medium 
without glycerol, which contains pyruvate, is used for culture of M. bovis. • L-asparagine- Nitrogen source The image below shows M.bovis colonies on LJ media. Mycobacterium tuberculosis colonies on LJ medium are dry, rough, raised and irregular with a 
wrinkled surface. They are creamy white or buff-colored, tenacious and difficult to 
emulsify(rough, tough, buff). 183 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 4: A 54-year-old male presents with an ulcer on his hand. On swab culture, growth of M. 
ulcerans is seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
184 
Sold by @itachibot Mycobacterium ulcerans causes Buruli ulcer. M. ulcerans produces a toxin called mycolactone which leads to formation of Buruli ulcer. This is 
a chronic, debilitating, necrotizing disease of the skin and soft tissue which is characterized by the 
formation of ulcers that progressively enlarge over time if left untreated. The ulcers heal with 
disfiguring scars. The image below shows a Buruli ulcer. Option A: Hunner's ulcers are seen in a subset of patients with interstitial cystitis. These are areas 
of inflammation on the bladder wall. The image below shows a cystoscopic image of a Hunner's ulcer. Option B: Meleney's ulcer or post-operative synergistic bacterial gangrene occurs in 
immuno-compromised individuals following abdominal surgery. It is caused by a synergistic 
interaction between microaerophilic nonhemolytic Streptococcus and hemolytic aerobic 
Staphylococcus aureus. 185 
Sold by @itachibot Option D: Marjolin ulcer is a rare and aggressive form of squamous cell carcinoma that grows 
from burns, scars, or poorly healing wounds. The image below shows a Marjolin's ulcer in a burn scar.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 42-year-old man who works at an aquarium and handles the fish without protective 
equipment presents to the OPD with the following finding. Infection with which of the 
following bacteria led to his condition?
questions.explanation:
The image shows a fish tank granuloma that is caused by M. marinum. The typical clinical presentation is as a single, small violet papule or nodule confined to one 
extremity, developing 2-3 weeks after trauma. The nodule may break down to form an indolent 
ulcer. M. marinarum is a natural pathogen of fish and amphibians, which spreads to humans who 
come in contact with contaminated swimming pools or fish tanks. Other non-tuberculous mycobacteria causing disease in humans include: • M. kansasii: Disease resembles pulmonary TB • M. scrofulaceum: Cervical lymphadenitis • M. avium complex: Pulmonary, disseminated TB, especially in AIDS patients • M. fortuitum: Nail salon furunculosis M. paratuberculosis (aka Johne’s bacillus) causes Johne’s disease in cattle. It is associated with 
Crohn’s disease in humans.

questions.question:
Question 6: Which of the following statements is true about the microbiological diagnosis of the disease 
afflicting the patient shown below? 179 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Acid fast staining is done by Ziehl-Neelsen technique, using 25% sulphuric acid
options.b: Sample should be collected from the centre of the lesion
options.c: The number of samples to be collected is 3-4
options.d: It is cultivated in nine banded armadillos and foot pads of mice

questions.explanation:
The image depicts leonine facies in a patient suffering from leprosy or Hansen's disease caused by 
Mycobacterium leprae. It is cultivated in nine-banded armadillos and footpads of mice. 186 
Sold by @itachibot M. leprae is a Gram-positive, weakly acid fast bacillus. Thus, 5% sulphuric acid (option A) is used 
for decolourisation to demonstrate M.leprae's acid-fastness. On microscopy, the bacilli appear 
bound together in masses called globi, within which they are arranged in a 'cigar bundle' 
appearance. For leprosy diagnosis, specimens are collected from the nasal mucosa, skin lesions and earlobes. 
Nasal smears are collected from the internal septum of the nose. Skin smears are collected from 
the edges of the lesions (option B) rather than from the centre. Slit skin smears are taken as well. 
The skin is pinched up tight to minimise bleeding and a cut is made with a scalpel, deep enough to 
get into the infiltrated layers. This is done over the buttocks, forehead, chin, cheek, and ears (at 
least 5-6 different areas) (option C).

questions.question: Question 7: What is the generation time of lepra bacilli?
questions.explanation:
The generation time of lepra bacilli is 12-13 days. Generation time, also known as doubling time, is the time it takes for the bacterial population to 
double. It can also be measured as the time between two cell divisions under optimum conditions. 
The generation time of different bacilli are given below: • Lepra bacilli- 12-13 days average (may vary from 8-42 days) • Tubercle bacilli- 15-20 hours • Coliform bacilli- 20 minutes

questions.question: Question 8: What are the bacteria present in Virchow's cells?
questions.explanation:
The bacteria present in Virchow’s cells is M. leprae. Lepromatous leprosy lesions contain large aggregates of lipid laden macrophages (lepra 
cells/Virchow cells) which are often filled with globi (masses) of acid fast bacilli. The image below shows a high-power Fite-Faraco stain of a skin lesion showing globi of M.leprae. 187 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 9: You counsel a patient with leprosy about lepra reactions before starting her on multidrug 
therapy. Which among these is correct regarding these reactions?
questions.explanation:
Statements 2, 4, and 5 regarding lepra reactions are correct. Type 2 lepra reactions are unrelated to drug therapy, whereas type 1 reactions may occur within a 
year of starting treatment. New lesions typically appear in type 2 lepra reactions. They are tender and erythematous 
subcutaneous and dermal nodules. Existing lesions show no changes.

questions.question:
Question 10: A patient diagnosed with leprosy was undergoing further evaluation for classification of type 
and immune response. Which of the following statements is false regarding the intradermal 
test used in such evaluation?

options.b: It has no value in prognostication of leprosy
options.d: BCG vaccine may convert a negative test to positive

questions.explanation:
The lepromin test has value as a prognostic test for leprosy. The lepromin, or Mitsuda test, is a method to measure cellular immunity in leprosy. It is a skin 
test for delayed hypersensitivity to lepra antigens. A bacillary suspension of inactivated M. leprae 
is injected just under the skin and the induration reaction is measured 3–4 weeks after. It is used to classify leprosy. A negative lepromin test is seen in lepromatous and borderline 
leprosy. It is negative in children <6 months of age, it may be positive at the end of 1st 
year. BCG vaccine is capable of converting a negative lepromin test to a positive.

questions.question:
Question 11: You are performing the test shown in the image on a patient. How many days later do you ask 
the patient to return so that you get an accurate read on the Mitsuda reaction? 181 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Mitsuda's reaction is read in the 3rd week, i.e., on the 21st day or 20 days after the day of 
injection. Lepromin test is a skin test for delayed hypersensitivity to lepra antigens. It is the only method for 
studying immunity in leprosy. A bacillary suspension of inactivated M. leprae is injected just 188 
Sold by @itachibot under the skin. The first reaction to occur is the early reaction of Fernandez, which consists of erythema and 
induration developing in 24-48 hours. It usually remains for 3-5 days; it is usually poorly defined 
and carries less significance. The second and more meaningful result is the late reaction of 
Mitsuda, starting at 1-2 weeks (7-10 days), reaching a peak in three or four weeks, and gradually 
subsiding over the next few weeks. On the 21st day, if there is a nodule more than 5 mm in 
diameter, the reaction is said to be positive. Note: The 21st day is 20 days after the day of injection which is counted as the 1st day.

questions.question:
Question 12: A leprosy vaccine is being introduced on a pilot basis in India. Which of the following 
mycobacterial species is the basis for its development?
questions.explanation:
Mycobacterium indicus pranii is the basis for the development of a leprosy vaccine. The leprosy vaccine species was originally called Mycobacterium W (M.w) but was later renamed 
Mycobacterium indicus pranii. The vaccine is administered via intradermal route. The dose is 0.1 
ml. It is divided into two equal doses and given on both arms. Booster doses will be given to maintain the immunity level. These are given only in one arm. 189 
Sold by @itachibot Escherichia, Proteus and Klebsiella
